abstracts.cdata!:
The Health Sector Management Project of
            Samoa had the following ratings: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was moderate, Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory, and borrower
            performance was moderately satisfactory. The lessons learned
            included: 1) Reform is not only a technical matter. The
            lesson seems to be that sector reform projects could benefit
            from socio-political analysis of the implications of the
            proposed reform and formulating a strategy to deal with
            potential bottlenecks, besides explicitly recognizing the
            high risk of delay or failure to take necessary decisions on
            the part of the Government; 2) There is a need to understand
            better institutional decision making processes. An
            institutional analysis, which provides an understanding of
            the way decisions are made within and across Ministries, is
            essential to ensure that the project is supported not only
            by champions within the Ministry, but has the backing of all
            the relevant units within and outside the counterpart agency
            that will be involved in authorizing or implementing project
            activities; 3) Focus on having clear and measurable project
            development objectives: Careful definition of the Project
            Development Objective and the identification of appropriate
            indicators that can be collected and which accurately
            reflect the intended impact are crucial for project
            evaluation purposes; 4) Coordination of donor inputs can be
            challenging under a loosely defined mechanism such as a
            Memorandum of Understanding; 5) Simplify and adapt
            procurement planning to country context especially in the
            context of a small country with a few important donors; 6)
            Sustaining capacity building is imperative. While projects
            typically support the building of individual capacity and
            the capacity of units within Ministries to perform, the
            mainstreaming and sustainability of capacity development
            continues to pose challenges; and 7 A lesson learned is that
            even when "lessons learned" are rightly identified
            during project preparation; they can resurface as a risk
            during project implementation.
